world

Class SimpleMap

  • java.lang.Object
    • world.SimpleMap

  • public class SimpleMap
extends java.lang.Object
    SimpleMap holds a 2d map for SimpleSolids, all the methods for adding and removing objects, as well as code for changing the z-index of a SimpleObject. It works by creating a doubly linked list for the draw order of each SimpleObject. The order in the list represents the order in which objects are drawn. The list for solids is maintained such that each solid is drawn in the order of the y-value of their cells. This automatic z-indexing is useful for games that have many moving objects on an isometric-ish surface.
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Brian Nakayama @ * @see SimpleWorld, Mark Groeneveld

    • Constructor Detail

      • SimpleMap

        public SimpleMap(int width,
         int height,
         int cellWidth,
         int cellHeight)
        Basic constructor initiates the map with Z-indexes 0-15. Index 8 is saved for SimpleSolid objects.
        Parameters:
        width - The width of the map in cells.
        height - The height of the map in cells.
        cellWidth - The width of the cells of the map.
        cellHeight - The height of the cells of the map.

      • SimpleMap

        public SimpleMap(int width,
         int height,
         int cellWidth,
         int cellHeight,
         int zWidth)
        Full constructor initiates the map with a chosen number of Z-indexes. Index number/2 will be saved for the SimpleSolidObjects.
        Parameters:
        width - The width of the map in cells.
        height - The height of the map in cells.
        cellWidth - The width of the cells of the map.
        cellHeight - The height of the cells of the map.
        zWidth - The number of Z-indexes.

    • Method Detail

      • addSimpleObject

        public boolean addSimpleObject(SimpleObject o,
                      int x,
                      int y)
        Adds a SimpleObject at the default index. This is either the solidIndex or solidIndex -1 (for SimpleObjects).
        Parameters:
        o - The SimpleObject to add to the map.
        x - The x-coordinate (in pixels)
        y - The y-coordinate (in pixels)
        Returns:
        True iff the object was successfully added.

      • addSimpleObject

        public boolean addSimpleObject(SimpleObject o,
                      int x,
                      int y,
                      int z)
        Adds a SimpleObject at the index given. If the object is a SimpleSolid, the given index is ignored and the object will be added with the SolidIndex. The z-index must be within the zWidth given in the constructor. This method also confirms that the object is not already part of a map. (0 <= z-index < zWidth)
        Parameters:
        o - The SimpleObject to add to the map.
        x - The x-coordinate (in pixels)
        y - The y-coordinate (in pixels)
        z - The z-index
        Returns:
        True iff the object was successfully added.

      • addSimpleSolid

        public boolean addSimpleSolid(SimpleSolid s,
                     int x,
                     int y)
        Adds a SimpleSolid to the solidIndex.
        Parameters:
        s - The SimpleObject to add to the map.
        x - The x-coordinate (in pixels)
        y - The y-coordinate (in pixels)
        Returns:
        True iff the object was successfully added.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Prints all of the objects currently registered to the map.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • calculateCollisions

        public SimpleObject[] calculateCollisions(int x,
                                 int y,
                                 SimpleObject s)
        Locates all of the possible collisions for an object of cellWidth and cellHeight colliding at a position x, y. Note, this will return a potential collision with itself. To check that there are no other collisions other than oneself the following code is recommended: 
         
 SimpleSolid[] collisions = m.getCollisions(x, y);
 if (collisions[0] == null || (collisions[0] == this && collisions[1] == null)) {
                etc...
        Parameters:
        x - The x position of the top left corner of the object.
        y - The y position of the top left corner of the object.
        Returns:
        An array (width = 4) containing up to 4 possible collisions.

      • removeSimpleObject

        public boolean removeSimpleObject(SimpleObject o)
        Removes a SimpleObject from the map. If the object is a solid, this method will first try to remove it from it's z-index and then it'll try to remove it from the map.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to be removed.
        Returns:
        True if the object was successfully removed.

      • removeSimpleSolid

        public boolean removeSimpleSolid(int x,
                        int y)
        Attempts to remove a SimpleSolid by its x and y coordinate on the grid. Notice, this is not the same as removing by the x and y pixel locations.
        Parameters:
        x - The x cell of the map.
        y - The y cell of the map
        Returns:
        True iff the object was in the map, and is now successfully removed.
        See Also:
        removeSimpleObject(SimpleObject)

      • clearAll

        public void clearAll()
        Removes all objects from the map.

      • changeZIndex

        public boolean changeZIndex(SimpleObject o,
                   int z)
        Changes the z index of a SimpleObject. This is done by removing the object, and then adding the object to a different zIndex.
        Parameters:
        o -
        z -
        Returns:
        False iff the object is not in the map or the object cannot be re-added (in which case it is just removed).
        See Also:
        removeSimpleObject(SimpleObject)

        public int getMapPixelWidth()
        Returns the max pixel at which an object can exist on the x-axis.
        Returns:
        The max pixel

      • getMapPixelHeight

        public int getMapPixelHeight()
        Returns the max pixel at which an object can exist on the y-axis.
        Returns:
        The max pixel
